A series of NiF2/AlF3 catalysts were prepared and tested for pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane. The effects of nickel precursors and reduction pretreatment on the catalytic performance were investigated. Compared to the NiAlF-N (with nitrate as the precursor) and NiAlF-A (with acetate as the precursor) catalysts, the NiAlF-C catalyst (with chloride as the precursor) with the lowest strong acidity gave the lowest initial reactivity (r 0 = 158.7 μmol g−1 min−1 at 500°C) but the best stability. The surface Lewis acid sites are the crucial active sites for C-F bond break, but excessive strong acid sites result in serious carbon deposition on the catalysts and thus drastic deactivation. Besides, the Ni0 species are new active sites for C-H activation, which accounts for the higher activity of the pre-reduced catalyst (denoted as NiAlF(H)) than that of the NiAlF. The NiAlF(H)-C catalyst gave a conversion of 29.2% and a high selectivity of 99% at 500 °C, also remained stable for 10 h. Its good performance was attributed to combined roles of surface Ni0 species and low amount of strong acid sites. Graphical abstract Catalytic pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane is of great importance for synthesis of trifluoroethylene. The amount of acid sites and metallic Ni0 species play crucial roles on the activity of the NiF2/AlF3 catalyst. The acid sites are responsible for the C-F bond activation and metallic Ni0 species are beneficial for the C-H bond activation. The strong acid sites would also result in the remarkable carbon deposition. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic pyrolysis NiF2/AlF3catalyst Trifluoroethylene Surface acid site Ni0 species 1 Introduction Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are generally considered as the potential alternatives for the ozone depleting substances (ODS) - chlorofluorocarbon (CFCs) in industrial applications. For instance, the usage of famous refrigerant freon has been remarkably decreased which is replaced by the ozone friendly 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane (HFC-134a) in domestic refrigeration systems, automotive air conditioning, and aerosol applications [1]. However, it is well known that HFC-134a is a greenhouse gas with a global warming potential (GWP) over 1300 [2]. Thus, the development of new generation refrigerant with low GWP and zero ozone depression potential (ODP) is in an urgent demand. For example, the new refrigerant 2,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234yf) replaced gradually HFC-134a has attracted much attention [3]. Catalytic pyrolysis of HFC-134a is also regarded as an ideal route, in which HFC-134a could be converted to high valuable and environmental friendly product trifluoroethylene (TrFE) [4,5]. In this sense, the development of efficient catalysts is of great importance for this reaction. Indeed, there are various metal oxides and fluorides catalysts employed for catalytic pyrolysis of HFC-134a to synthesize trifluoroethylene, including Al2O3 [6,7], AlF3 [8], NiO/Al2O3 [9], Mg/Al2O3 [10], and Ga/Al2O3 [11]. However, low activity and poor stability are the main issues of these catalysts. Much attention has been paid to the improvement of stability of catalyst, but it is still very challenging. For instance, among various crystal phases (γ, α, η, κ, β, θ) of Al2O3 catalysts, θ-Al2O3 catalyst gave the highest activity with a conversion of 35.1% and a trifluoroethylene selectivity of 99.0% at 450 °C, but the hydrofluoric acid corrosion lead to the severe catalyst deactivation [6]. Thus, acid-resistant AlF3 catalysts with α-, β- and θ-phases were used for the reaction, and it was found that the stability could be improved and the θ-AlF3 catalyst exhibited the highest reactivity compared to the β-AlF3 and α-AlF3 catalysts [8]. Other factors have also been considered which significantly affect the catalytic performance. It was pointed that presence of water vapor would resist the deactivation of γ-Al2O3 catalyst during the catalytic pyrolysis reaction of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane [7]. The treatment of catalyst by sulfuric acid or hydrofluorination also has effect on the activity and stability [11,12]. Nickel precursors often affect the catalytic performance in catalytic reforming [13], methanation and hydrogenation of CO2 [14,15], due to the change of nickel oxides state, surface hydroxyl group, etc. Yet, nickel precursors have been rarely discussed for the catalytic pyrolysis reaction of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane. It is well known that Lewis acid sites play important roles on the activation of C-F bonds, which is the key step for the catalytic pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane [12,16]. Teinz et al. [17] found that the AlF3 catalyst gave exclusively high selectivity toward dehydrofluorination for pyrolysis of 3-chloro-1,1,1,3-tetrafluorobutane, which was attributed to its abundant strong Lewis acid sites. Li et al. [16,18] demonstrated that the medium strength Lewis acid sites were the crucial active sites for catalytic pyrolysis of CF3CH3. Okazaki et al. [19] pointed that the product distributions obviously depended on the strength of acid sties. Nevertheless, the remarkable drawback of the strong acid sites is the carbon deposition arising on the catalyst surface, which results in the serious catalyst deactivation [6]. However, the relationships between Lewis acid sites with reactivity and deactivation rate of catalysts for 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane pyrolysis have been hardly investigated. 3 Herein, a series of nickel based fluoride catalysts (NiF2/AlF3) derived by different nickel precursors were prepared for the catalytic pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane. The prepared catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Raman spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The deactivation kinetics and asymptote rate of the catalysts were also investigated. Based on the evaluation on catalytic performance and the detailed characterizations, the roles of surface acidity and Ni species on the catalytic performance were discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported NiF2/AlF3 catalysts derived from different nickel precursors (e.g., Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, NiCl2·6H2O and C4H6NiO4·4H2O) were prepared by a facile process of impregnation and subsequent gaseous fluorination. Typically, 2 g of γ phase aluminum oxide (20–30 mesh) was dispersed in an aqueous solution containing a certain amount of nickel precursor. Then, the mixture was dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The dried solid was calcined in air at 550 °C for 4 h, and NiO/Al2O3 sample was obtained. The NiO/Al2O3 samples were denoted to NiAlO-N, NiAlO-C and NiAlO-A, corresponding to nickel precursors of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, NiCl2·6H2O and NiC4H6O4·4H2O, respectively. Afterwards, the NiO/Al2O3 samples were fluorinated by gaseous HF (40% HF + 60% N2) at 400 °C for 4 h, and the obtained catalysts were denoted as NiAlF3-N, NiAlF3-C and NiAlF3-A. For the pre-reduced catalysts, the NiAlO-N, NiAlO-C and NiAlO-A catalysts were reduced by H2 at 400 °C for 2 h, and then were fluorinated by gaseous HF (40% HF + 60% N2) at 400 °C for 4 h. The resulting catalysts were denoted as NiAlF(H)-N, NiAlF(H)-C and NiAlF(H)-A catalysts, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The surface areas of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K on a JW-BK200C apparatus. Before the measurement, the sample was dried at 100 °C overnight and outgassed at 200 °C for 4 h under vacuum. The Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method was employed to calculate the specific area. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images was obtained on a Hitachi S-4800, the catalyst power was directly imbedded in conductive tapes, with an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were recorded on a Tecnai 20 operating with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The XRD patterns were collected under a Focus D8 powder diffractometer (40 kV, Cu Kα) in the 2θ range of 10–80° with a step width of 0.02°. Then the software MID-JADE 6.0 was used to analysis the phase composition. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were carried on an RBD upgraded PHI-5000CESCA system (Perkin Elmer) using a Mg Kα radiation (hν = 1253.6 eV) operated at 14.0 kV. Binding energies were calibrated using the adventitious carbon (C1s = 284.6 eV). NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were measured on an automatic Finesorb-3010 characterization system. For the NH3-TPD test, 100 mg of catalyst was pre-treated in a quartz U-tube reactor (i.d. = 6 mm, length = 250 mm) at 500 °C for 30 min under a N2 flow (10 ml min−1). After the sample was cooled down to 100 °C, a flow of NH3 (10 ml min−1) was introduced for 20 min at 100 °C. Afterwards, both the gaseous and physisorbed NH3 were purged by a N2 flow (10 ml min−1). The sample was heated from 100 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 15 °C min−1 using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to monitor the desorbed NH3. For the H2-TPR test, 150 mg of the catalyst was put into a quartz U-tube reactor and reduced in a mixed H2 flow (10% H2/ 90% Ar, v/v) from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. H2 consumption was continuously monitored with a TCD detector. The total amount of NH3 desorbed was exactly determined by the adsorption with an excess of dilute HCl and following the titration with NaOH solution. Pyridine (Py) absorbed infrared spectrum (Py-IR) was conducted at 200 °C using a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer in the spectral range 1700–1400 cm−1. Raman spectra were recorded under ambient conditions using a Renishaw Invia reflex Raman spectrometer with a 325 nm Ar laser beam. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment was performed using a Netzsch STA 449C instrument. 2.3 Catalytic testing The reaction was carried out on a fixed bed reactor equipped with an electric heater. Typically, 2.0 ml of NiAlF catalyst was loaded into the reactor and heated from room temperature to 500 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in N2. Then, a mixture gas of N2 (40 ml/min) and 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane (HFC-134a) (20 ml/min) was introduced into the reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled by a thermocouple. The product gas was firstly pre-treated with a KOH solution to remove the HF gas and then analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a GS-GASPRO capillary column (60 m × 0.32 mm). 2.4 Catalyst deactivation kinetics study The power-law equation presented below can be obtained from the time stream results to calculate the rate of deactivation in each reaction (Eqs. (1) & (2)): (1) r dec = − d a d t = k dec · a d (2) r dec = k dec · ( 1 1 + k dec · t n ) d Where: a = Relative rate (defined as the trifluoroethylene yield at t divided by the initial trifluoroethylene yield at t = 0) k dec = Deactivation rate constant d = Order of deactivation (d = 1, 2, and 3) n = Fouling parameter This decay mechanism is widely recognized in the reactions involving hydrocarbons, which is ascribed to the formation of deposited carbon on the catalyst surfaces [20]. 2.5 Zero asymptote rate Eq. (3) below calculates the zero-asymptote rate. It is a classic first-order deactivation model with an assumption that a zero rate will be asymptotically approached by the catalyst at an infinite time on stream. The integrated form is shown in the following Eq. (4): (3) d a d t = − k d · a ; a = r ( t ) r 0 ; d a a = − k d · d t Integrated Form (4) r ( t ) = e − k d · t · r 0 Where: r 0 = Initial rate kd = Deactivation constant The two parameters above require fitting, which can be accomplished by the software origin 2021b. 2.6 Non-zero asymptote rate Eq. (5) and Eq. (6) below calculates the non-zero asymptote rate. It is a first order deactivation model with a assumption that a steady state rate will be asymptotically approached by the catalyst at infinite time on stream. The integrated form is shown in the following Eq. (7): (5) a = r ( t ) r 0 ; a s s = r ( t → ∞ ) r 0 ; d a d t = − k d · ( a − a s s ) (6) d a a − a s s = − k d · d t ; a s s = r s s r 0 Integrated Form: (7) r ( t ) = e − k d · t · ( r 0 − r s s ) + r s s Where: r 0 = Initial rate kd = Deactivation constant a ss = Relative rate r ss = Steady state rate The three parameters above require fitting, which can be accomplished by the software origin 2021b. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 General characterization Table 1 lists the specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter results of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts. There are some slight differences in specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter for the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts prepared by different nickel precursor. Compared to the NiAlF-C and NiAlF-A catalysts, the NiAlF-N catalyst shows the largest specific surface area (51 m2 g−1) and the smallest average pore diameter (23.2 nm). However, the NiAlF-N catalyst gives the lowest pore volume of 0.26 cm3 g−1. The above results suggest that the nickel salt precursor has significant effect on the porosity of the NiAlF catalysts. For the NiAlF(H) catalysts obtained by reducing and fluorinating NiAlO catalysts, the surface areas are similar to the corresponding NiAlF catalysts, such as the specific surface area of 51 m2 g−1 of NiAlF(H)-N catalyst, indicating that the H2 reduction has no influence on the porosity of the catalysts. N2 adsorption isotherms and pore diameter distributions of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts are shown in Fig. S1. The adsorption isotherms of all the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts are type IV with obvious hysteresis loops (Fig. S1a and b), which are the superposition of H3 and H4 [21]. Combined with the type of hysteresis loop and the pore diameter distributions, it can be inferred that there are mainly accumulated mesopores in the catalysts. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of various catalysts. The NiAlO samples prepared by different nickel precursors give same diffraction peaks of Al2O3 and NiO (PDF#: 73-1519) in Fig. 1 a. The appearance of weak diffraction peak ascribed to spinel NiAl2O4 (PDF#: 77-1877) indicates its low content in NiAlO samples ( Fig. 1 a). After the hydrofluorination of NiAlO samples, the metal oxides of Al2O3 and NiO in the NiAlO samples were transformed into AlF3 (PDF#: 44-0231) and NiF2 (PDF#: 76-0605) ( Fig. 1 b). The diffraction peak at 25.1o assigned to (012) facet of AlF3 in NiAlF-C catalyst is obviously weaker and wider than that of the NiAlF-N and NiAlF-A catalysts, suggesting the smaller particles of AlF3 in the NiAlF-C catalyst. The crystallite size of AlF3 particles in the NiAlF-C catalysts is 16.1 nm calculated by Scherrer equation, while those in the NiAlF-A and NiAlF-N catalysts are 26.8 and 20.1 nm, respectively. Whereas, the appearance of weak diffraction peaks at 27.0 and 52.7° assigned to NiF2 specie suggests its low crystallinity or amorphous structure in the NiAlF catalysts ( Fig. 1 b). For the NiAlO(H) catalysts, the characteristic peaks of Al2O3 are observed at 46.9 and 66.5°, and the characteristic peaks of NiO appear at 7.2 and 62.9°, the formation of Ni0 species can be evidenced by the appearance of characteristic peaks at 43.9 and 50.8°. Compared to the NiAlO(H)-A and NiAlO(H)-N catalysts, the NiAlO(H)-C catalyst possesses the strongest diffraction peak at 43.9o assigned to the (111) facet metallic Ni, suggesting the bigger crystalline size or more Ni0 species in the NiAlO(H)-C catalyst. This observation implies that the NiO species in NiAlO samples derived by different nickel salts precursors show different reducibility. The weak diffraction peaks ascribed to NiAl2O4 appear in the NiAlO(H) samples ( Fig. 1 c). After the hydrofluorination of the NiAlO(H) samples, the characteristic diffraction peaks of AlF3 and NiF2 species could also be observed as shown in the patterns of NiAlF(H) catalysts. And the sizes of AlF3 particles are close to 21-22 nm for all the NiAlF(H) catalysts. However, the diffraction peak at 43.9o is still observed in the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst ( Fig. 1 d), suggesting the existence of metallic Ni. This result can be explained by that the inner part of big metallic Ni particles in the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst remains the metallic state after hydrofluorination. All these catalysts are particles aggregation without any feature morphology based on the SEM images in Fig. S2. The TEM and HRTEM images of the representative NiAlF(H)-C catalyst are shown in Fig. 2 a–d. According to the TEM images ( Fig. 2 a), the average size of metallic Ni particle in the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst is analyzed, and the mean size of metallic Ni particle is about 4 nm ( Fig. 2 b). As seen in the HRTEM images, the AlF3 and metallic Ni species clearly present in the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst. The lattice spacing of 0.35437 nm is assigned to the (012) facet of AlF3species, and the lattice spacing of 0.20236 nm is attributed to the (111) facet of metallic Ni species [22]. These easily exposed facets of AlF3 and metallic Ni species in the HRTEM images should be ascribed to their abundant ratios in the crystal which is evidenced by XRD patterns with the strongest diffraction peaks. Fig. 3 shows the XPS spectra of Ni2p in the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts to investigate the surface Ni species (i.e., Ni0, Ni2+ and Ni3+). The peaks with binding energy at 840.0-880.0 eV are assigned to the Ni2p3/2, and the satellite peaks of Ni element can be found at binding energy of 870.0-880.0 eV [23–25]. For the NiAlF-A, NiAlF-C and NiAlF-N catalysts, the peaks with binding energy at 856.0 eV and 863.0 eV are assigned to the Ni2p3/2 of Ni2+ and Ni3+ species ( Fig. 3 a), respectively. For the NiAlF(H)-A, NiAlF(H)-C and NiAlF(H)-N catalysts, besides with the Ni2+ and Ni3+ species, a new peak at binding energy of 852.4 eV is attributed to the Ni2p3/2 of Ni0 species [26–29]. The important effect of nickel precursor on Ni species loading for the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts were strongly confirmed by the XPS results. Table 2 lists the surface atom content and the ratios of surface Ni species. It could be seen that there are main Ni2+ species in both the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts. Among the NiAlF catalysts, the NiAlF-C catalyst possesses the lowest Ni total element concentration (1.61 mol.%), whereas its Ni3+ relative ratio (0.19) is the highest. The NiAlF-N catalyst has the highest surface Ni species (element concentration of 3.46%) and the lowest Ni3+ relative ratio (0.14). For the same nickel salt precursors of catalyst, the NiAlF(H)-C has the lowest Ni element concentration (2.06 %) and the highest Ni3+ relative ratio (0.27) among the NiAlF(H) catalysts. Besides, the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst gives the highest ratio (0.15) of Ni0 species. Fig. 4 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts. The profiles can be divided into three regions (I, II and III) ( Fig. 4 ). The region I in the low temperature is corresponding to the NH3 desorption from the weak acid sites; the region II in the temperature range of 225–350 °C is assigned to the NH3 desorption from the medium acid sites; the region III at temperature higher than 350 °C is assigned to the NH3 desorption from strong acid sties [30,31]. Thus, the amount of weak, medium and strong acid sites can be quantified, and there are main strong acid sites in these catalysts. The total amount of acid sites was listed in Table 3 . It could be seen that the NiAlF-C catalyst has the lowest acid amount of 0.674 mmol g−1 compared to the NiAlF-A (0.887 mmol g−1) and NiAlF-N (0.722 mmol g−1) catalysts. For the NiAlF(H) catalysts, the total amount of acid sites of the NiAlF(H)-C and NiAlF(H)-A catalysts slightly decrease compared to the corresponding NiAlF catalysts, whereas the NiAlF(H)-N catalyst shows a higher amount of acid sites than the NiAlF-N catalyst. The surface Al and Ni element content ( Table 2 ) are related to the acid site amount of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalyst. Both the NiAlF-C and NiAlF(H)-C catalysts have relatively low amount of strong acid sites, which may be attributed to the low Ni2+ species ratio on the surface of catalysts. The types of acid sites were determined by the infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption on the typical NiAlF-C and NiAlF(H)-C catalysts, and the results were shown in Fig. S3. The remarkable bands at 1454 and 1622 cm−1 are assigned to the ν 19b and ν 8a characteristic vibration modes of pyridine ring breathing on the Lewis acid sites of the NiAlF-C catalyst, respectively [32–34]. For the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst, both the ν 19b and ν 8a vibration bands of pyridine ring can also be found at 1451 and 1619 cm−1, respectively. These observations suggest that there are main Lewis acid sites on the NiAlF-C and NiAlF(H)-C catalyst. All the NiAlF catalysts are directly derived from NiAlO catalysts by hydrofluorination, whereas all the NiAlF(H) catalysts are derived from NiAlO catalysts by reduction and subsequent hydrofluorination. It is necessary to investigate the reducibility of NiO species and its interaction with Al2O3 for the NiAlO catalysts with different precursors. Fig. 5 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the NiAlO catalysts to investigate the reducibility of NiO species and its interaction with Al2O3. For the NiAlO-C catalyst, three reduction peaks assigned to NiO species are observed at temperature range of 150°C (α), 300–420 °C (β) and 420–620 °C (γ) [35]. For the NiAlO-N and NiAlO-A catalysts, the similar H2-TPR profiles are obtained, three reduction peaks assigned to NiO species are observed at temperature range of 300–400 °C (β) and 400–550 °C (β′), and 550–620 °C (γ). This observation suggests the same reducibility of NiO species in the NiAlO-N and NiAlO-A catalysts. The reduction peak α in the NiAlO-C catalyst indicates the existence of easily reduced NiO species, suggesting the weak interactions of NiO species with Al2O3 [35]. The reduction peak β at medium high temperature (300–400 °C) is corresponding to the NiO species with medium reducibility (medium metal-support interactions). The reduction peak γ at high temperature (420–620 °C) can be assigned to the nickel-aluminum oxide species derived from strong interaction between NiO and Al2O3, which may be spinel crystal structure of NiAl2O4 [36]. 3.2 Evaluation of catalytic activities It is well known that a rigorous reaction condition is demanded for the fluorinated alkanes pyrolysis to synthesize fluorinated olefins. The fluorinated alkanes pyrolysis includes the cleavage of C-F and C-H [37], that is a dehydrofluorination process. The cleavage of C-F bond commonly needs high reaction temperature due to its high dissociation energy (522.0 ± 8.4 kJ mol−1), such as 1,1-difluoroethane [17], 1,1,1-trifluoroethane [18]. In addition, the remarkable deactivation of catalyst for the dehydrofluorination process is also a serious issue which needs to be addressed. The pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane to synthesize trifluoroethylene was conducted over the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts, the reaction equation is shown in following: CF3CH2F → CF2=CHF + HF, △r H θ(298K) = 128.6 kJmol−1 [38]. Fig. 6 shows the catalytic activities of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts for 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane pyrolysis to trifluoroethylene. Both the yields of trifluoroethylene and relative rate (a) are plotted against time on stream (TOS). From the Fig. 6 a, the initial yields of trifluoroethylene are only in slight difference for these three catalysts, namely 35.5% for the NiAlF-C, 35.7% for the NiAlF-A, and 36.0% for the NiAlF-N catalysts, and their selectivity is up to 98.0%. Drastic deactivation is observed on all the catalysts. The function between relative rate (a) and time on steam (t) are evaluated by fitting power-law models ( Eqs. (1 ) and (2 )) for the NiAlF catalysts, the deactivation rate constants (kdec ), fouling parameter (n) and R2 value are shown in Table 4 . Among them, the NiAlF-C catalyst gave the lowest deactivation rate constants kdec (2.3423 × 10−4 min−1), namely, the highest stability for the pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane. Fig. 6 b shows the yields and relative rate of the NiAlF(H) catalysts, and the deactivation rate constants (kdec ) were also investigated. Compared to the NiAlF catalysts, the higher initial reaction activities are observed over the corresponding NiAlF(H) catalysts. In addition, the highest initial activity was obtained on the NiAlF(H)-N catalyst with the yield of 39.3%, whereas the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst gave the robust stability with the lowest deactivation rate constants kdec . The deactivation rate constants kdec of these catalysts are in order: NiAlF(H)-N (kdec = 0.5466 × 10−4 min−1) > NiAlF(H)-A (kdec = 0.3233 × 10−4 min−1) > NiAlF(H)-C (kdec = 0.2133 × 10−4 min−1). And the deactivation rate constant (kdec ) of the NiAlF(H) catalyst is much lower than that of the corresponding NiAlF catalyst. Thus, both the reactivity and stability could be improved for the NiAlF(H) catalyst compared to the corresponding NiAlF catalyst. To successfully get a precise original rateon a fresh catalyst surface and understand the real deactivation of catalyst, the non-zero rate asymptoteand the zero rate asymptote of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts were investigated and the shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S4, respectively. Fig. 7 shows the mass specific reaction rate of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts for the pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane, and the non-zero rate asymptote model ( Eq. (7 )) was adopted to fit the deactivation of reaction rate. The initial reaction rates (r 0), deactivation rate constants (kd ) and R2 value are listed in Table 3 , which is used to more intuitively differentiate the stability of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts. Obviously, the initial reaction rates (r0 ) of the as-reduced NiAlF(H) catalysts are improved compared to the corresponding NiAlF catalysts. Among the NiAlF catalysts, the NiAlF-C catalyst has the lowest deactivation constants (kd = 0.741 × 10−4 min−1). Besides, the zero rate asymptote model ( Eq. (4 )) for the NiAlF catalysts shown in Fig. S4a-c, it is also found the lowest kd (8.091 × 10−2 min−1) for the NiAlF-C catalyst. For the NiAlF(H) catalysts, the non-zero rate asymptote model ( Eq. (7 )) has a high fitting degree (R 2 > 0.981), whereas the zero rate asymptote for the NiAlF(H) catalyst in Fig. S4e-f has the low fitting degree, with the R2 value less than 0.891. The deactivation constants (kd ) shown Table 3 are in order: NiAlF(H)-C (kd = 0.8571 × 10−4 min−1) < NiAlF(H)-N (kd = 1.0955 × 10−4 min−1) < NiAlF(H)-A (kd = 1.3334 × 10−4 min−1). This observation confirms the excellent catalytic stability of the NiAlF(H)-C catalysts for pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane. 3.3 Discussion the roles of acid sites and Ni0 species on catalytic performances The Lewis acid sites are widely regarded as the crucial acid sites for C-F bond break during the pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane to trifluoroethylene [10,39,40]. Thus, the relationship between initial mass specific reaction rates (r0 ) and the total acidic amount is constructed as shown in Fig. 8 . It could be seen that the initial reaction rates (r0 ) of NiAlF catalysts increase with increasing amount of total acid sites. Therefore, the NiAlF-N catalyst with the highest total acid amount gives the highest initial mass specific reaction rate of 168.4 μmolg−1 min−1. And the trend of the NiAlF(H) catalysts is similar to that of the NiAlF catalysts, further confirming the important role of acid sites for the reactivity. Compared to the NiAlF catalysts, the enhanced catalytic activities observed on the NiAlF(H) catalysts can be attributed to the existence metallic Ni0 species. Although Lewis acid sites are responsible for the C-F bond activation, the metallic Ni0 species could act as active sites to activate the C-H bond which is beneficial for the pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane to trifluoroethylene [41–43]. Such as the NiAlF-C catalyst with more total acid sites amounts (0.674 mmol g−1, r0 = 158.8 μmol g−1 min−1) gives lower reactivity than the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst (0.617 mmol g−1, r0 = 168.7 μmol g−1 min−1), because there are abundant metallic Ni0 species in the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst as evidence by XRD ( Fig. 1 ) and XPS ( Fig. 3 ) results. In order to reveal the mechanism of catalyst deactivation, the Raman spectra and the TG analysis results of the spent NiAlF and NiAlF(H)catalysts are shown in the Fig. 9 . All the NiAlF or NiAlF(H) catalysts give the similar bands at 1347 and 1601 cm−1, which are assigned to amorphous and graphitic deposited carbon, respectively [44]. In addition, the NiAlF-C catalyst gives the lowest intensity of Raman band and weight loss of only 9.65%, whereas the NiAlF-C catalyst also gives the lowest deactivation constants (kd ), implying its highest catalytic stability. Compared to the NiAlF catalysts, the NiAlF(H) catalysts show lower intensity of Raman band and weight loss, especially for NiAlF(H)-C catalyst with only 3.53% weight loss. The active sites such as Lewis acid sites covered by deposited carbon would result in the remarkable deactivation [40], thus, the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst covered by lowest deposited carbon shows the highest stability. The strong acid sites are commonly considered as the crucial sites for the carbon deposition, thus, the relationships between surface strong acid sites and carbon deposition of the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts are investigated as shown in Fig. 10 . For the NiAlF catalysts, the amount of carbon deposition and deactivation constants (kd ) increase with the strong acid sites increased ( Fig. 10 a), implying the important role of strong acid sites on the carbon deposition. For the NiAlF(H) catalysts, the same tendency can be observed, further demonstrating that the strong acid sites as a main factor impact on the deactivation across the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts. The carbon of fluorine olefins could easily deposit on the strong acid sites and thus the serious carbon deposition occurred [16]. For the pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane to synthesize trifluoroethylene, the carbon deposition was formed by cracking reaction of trifluoroethylene on the surface strong acid sties of catalysts. 4 Conclusion The NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts derived from nickel nitrate, chloride and acetate precursors were prepared by impregnation and tested for pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane to synthesize trifluoroethylene. The effects of nickel salt precursors and H2 reduction on the catalytic activity and stability of NiF2/AlF3 catalyst were investigated. The amount of acid sites and metallic Ni0 species play synergistic effect on the pyrolysis reactivity. The acid sites are responsible for the C-F bond activation and metallic Ni0 species are beneficial for the C-H bond activation. Whereas, the strong acid sites would also result in the remarkable carbon deposition, thus the obviously deactivation is observed in the NiAlF and NiAlF(H) catalysts. The NiAlF(H)-N catalyst with the most amount of acid sites gives the highest initial specific reaction rate, however, the NiAlF(H)-C catalyst with most metallic Ni0 species and lowest amount of strong acid sites exhibits the highest catalytic stability. coredata.dc:description: A series of NiF2/AlF3 catalysts were prepared and tested for pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane. The effects of nickel precursors and reduction pretreatment on the catalytic performance were investigated. Compared to the NiAlF-N (with nitrate as the precursor) and NiAlF-A (with acetate as the precursor) catalysts, the NiAlF-C catalyst (with chloride as the precursor) with the lowest strong acidity gave the lowest initial reactivity (r 0 = 158.7 μmol g−1 min−1 at 500°C) but the best stability. The surface Lewis acid sites are the crucial active sites for C-F bond break, but excessive strong acid sites result in serious carbon deposition on the catalysts and thus drastic deactivation. Besides, the Ni0 species are new active sites for C-H activation, which accounts for the higher activity of the pre-reduced catalyst (denoted as NiAlF(H)) than that of the NiAlF. The NiAlF(H)-C catalyst gave a conversion of 29.2% and a high selectivity of 99% at 500 °C, also remained stable for 10 h. Its good performance was attributed to combined roles of surface Ni0 species and low amount of strong acid sites.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic roles of surface acidity and Ni species in NiF2/AlF3 catalysts for pyrolysis of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane
